p: Use implicit differentiation to find the points where the circle defined by $f = $d has horizontal and vertical tangent lines.
The circle has horizontal tangent lines at the point(s) $ans1
The circle has vertical tangent lines at the point(s) $ans2

solution.p: By completing squares, the equation of the circle can be written as (x - $a)^2 + (y - $b)^2 = $c2. Then, differentiating implicitly with respect to x, gives 2(x - $a) + 2(y - $b) \, \frac{dy}{dx} = 0, or \frac{dy}{dx} = - \frac{x - $a}{y - $b}. The tangent line to the circle is horizontal where \frac{dy}{dx} = 0, i.e., where x = $a, which gives (y - $b)^2 = $c2, or y = $b \pm $c = $an1a, $an1b. Hence, the tangent line to the circle is horizontal at the points $ans1.

The tangent line to the circle is vertical where 0 = \frac{dx}{dy} = - \frac{y - $b}{x - $a}, i.e., where y = $b, which gives (x - $a)^2 = $c2, or x = $a \pm $c = $an2a, $an2b. Hence, the tangent line to the circle is vertical at the points $ans2.
(Notice that this problem could be solved without differentiating, once the centre and radius of the circle are identified.)
